results.title: The Long Now
results.brief_description: There is a giant clock ringing deep inside a mountain in the belly of the Sierra Diablo Ranges - The land of the Devil. It is a huge clock, hundreds of feet tall, designed to tick for 10,000 years. The mountain in which the clock resides is privately owned by Jeff Bezos. Programmed never to chime the same melody twice, its anyone’s guess how many beautiful songs will never be heard over the clock’s 10 millennial lifespan. Xanthe Dobbie’s new experimental desktop performance ponders the human urge to seek immortality. Featuring original epic hero Gilgamesh and the disembodied deep fake voice of Alan Rickman, The Long Now collapses histories, illuminating ancient and contemporary myth-making practices.

results.title: The Silenced
results.credit_line:
Julie Gough

Single-channel video, sound, 6:18 mins.

ACMI Collection

Edited by Jemma Rae
results.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
results.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough
description_for_label:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

In works such as The Silenced, Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.”

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-08. How We Tell Our Stories → MA-08-AV01

results.title: Delivery Dancer's Arc: 0° Receiver
results.brief_description: South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Deliver Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver.

constellations_primary.name: Hard sci-fi to cyberpunk
constellations_primary.description: Ayoung Kim's practice has been inspired by 'hard' science fiction writers like Greg Egan. Recent sci-fi media using hard sci-fi can be connected back to the beginnings of cyberpunk, a sub-genre of sci-fi.

results.description:
South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver. Drawing on influences that range from Blade Runner (1982)’s techno-futurist cityscapes to an 18th-century Indian astronomical observatory, Kim twists sci-fi tropes into a speculative story rich with otherworldly doubles, interdimensional journeys and colliding worlds.

From a high-octane motorcycle chase through ancient ruins to a cat-and-mouse game down neon streets, an ordinary delivery driver must outrun her enemies and embrace her destiny to save time-keeping traditions across possible worlds. With a dynamic mix of live-action footage, app interfaces, CGI avatars and landscapes powered by game engines, Kim uses the tools of screen culture and our hyper-networked age to question time, productivity and the self.
description_for_label:
South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver. Drawing on influences that range from Blade Runner (1982)’s techno-futurist cityscapes to an 18th-century Indian astronomical observatory, Kim twists sci-fi tropes into a speculative story rich with otherworldly doubles, interdimensional journeys and colliding worlds.

From a high-octane motorcycle chase through ancient ruins to a cat-and-mouse game down neon streets, an ordinary delivery driver must outrun her enemies and embrace her destiny to save time-keeping traditions across possible worlds. With a dynamic mix of live-action footage, app interfaces, CGI avatars and landscapes powered by game engines, Kim uses the tools of screen culture and our hyper-networked age to question time, productivity and the self.

results.title: Le Tresor des Hollandais
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Une Nuit a L'opera
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
Stephane is locked up on the roof of the Opera House with the real jewels still in his bag. After owning up to Morales, he is forced to return to the Opera and make a second attempt of substitution under the watchful eye of Lulu, Morales’ accomplice. As they reach the dressing rooms, they are interrupted by a night watchman doing his round.

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.

results.title: Un 'diam' Pour Jacinthe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
Alerted by Inspector Boudot, the Canadian Police starts to follow Stephane. Gloria manages to speak to Olympe about Stephane’s trouble with both Morales and the law. She also tells her where the jewels have been hidden.

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.

results.title: Sur les Bords du Saint-Laurent
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
Today is the day for Jacinthe and Bicou to present for their dance exam. Jacinthe gives her precious ring to Bicou’s father for tightening. He is quick to realise that the ring is not a prop but a high quality diamond.

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.

results.title: Les Anges de la Route
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
Olympe and the last members of the Corps de Ballet are finally on their way to the airport. On the roof of their car, they are carrying a huge accessories basket containing Coppelia and the treasure. Not far behind, Stephane and Lulu are making sure that the basket duly goes through customs. Stephane who was due to take his cabaret show to Las Vegas is informed by Morales that he must follow the ballet to Canada and supervise the return of the real jewels to the Canadian contact. Meanwhile, the injured nightwatchman is making interesting revelations to Inspector Boudot.

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.

results.title: Le Sac a Malices
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
The Canadian Police now suspects Olympe to have run away with the real jewels. Stephane must hand back an empty bag to his accomplices. Lulu and Morales make a last attempt at terrorising the children into handing back the necklace and the ring.

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.

results.title: Le Nouveau Monde
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Le Tresor des Hollandais”.
On arrival in Canada, Olympe arouses suspiscion from the Canadian Customs. Stephane is considering abadonning Morales and his plans, but the threat to compromise Olympe with the smuggling of stolen goods is enough to keep him going. Lulu is still trying, not so subtly, to snatch the necklace from the children,

Credits: Director, Philippe Agostini; writer, Odette Joyeux; photography, Christian Petard; music, Georges Auric; choreography, Michel Descombey; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Claude Bessy, Claude Ariel, Catherine Bouchy, Pierre Didier, Felix Marten, Jacques Fabbri, Robert Manuel.
